Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Deep Brain Stimulation vs. Levodopa on Autonomic Nervous System Functions in Parkinson's Disease

Trial_Design.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 29 PD patients.

Intervention.evidence: Fourteen patients received STN stimulation, and 15 received levodopa.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to evaluate the effects of subthalamic nucleus (STN) deep brain stimulation on ANS functions compared to levodopa.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in cardiovascular ANS functions, measured by blood pressure (BP) and heart rate (HR) during rest and orthostatic conditions, heart rate variability (HRV), and breathing-induced cutaneous sympathetic vasoconstriction (CVC).

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Blinding was not applicable due to the nature of the interventions.

Number_Randomised.evidence: This randomised controlled trial included 29 PD patients.

Result_Outcome.evidence: STN stimulation did not significantly affect cardiovascular ANS functions but significantly increased CVC. In contrast, levodopa significantly lowered BP and HR at rest and increased orthostatic hypotension.

Harms.evidence: No adverse events were reported in either group.
